content.raw: Ah, that makes perfect sense. #552 is running for `ign-transport3` which was only able to compile as a static library. These warnings only occur when you compile as a shared library, which is something we only started doing in `ign-transport4`.
content.html: Ah, that makes perfect sense. #552 is running for ign-transport3 which was only able to compile as a static library. These warnings only occur when you compile as a shared library, which is something we only started doing in ign-transport4.

content.raw: Maybe Jenkins just compares the number of warnings with the previous job because #552 is blue. We can tackle the warnings in a separate PR then.
content.html: Maybe Jenkins just compares the number of warnings with the previous job because #552 is blue. We can tackle the warnings in a separate PR then.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

content.raw:
Do we know what branch those warnings are being compared to? I believe most (if not all) of those are already being exhibited on the `default` branch.

Almost all of them are C4251, which can only occur by introducing new templated member variables to a class. We don't introduce any new member variables in this PR.
content.html:
Do we know what branch those warnings are being compared to? I believe most (if not all) of those are already being exhibited on the default branch.

Almost all of them are C4251, which can only occur by introducing new templated member variables to a class. We don't introduce any new member variables in this PR.

content.raw: Agreed, I'd rather move it inside `IsValidNamespace()`.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

content.raw:
Looks like `IsValidNamespace` should return true if `_partition` is empty, so seems like we can remove it.

On the other hand, checking if its empty first would shortcut the tests that get performed inside of `IsValidNamespace`, so it might be a micro-optimization. I suppose would could achieve that same micro-optimization by starting off `IsValidNamespace` by checking if the string is empty.
content.html:
Looks like IsValidNamespace should return true if _partition is empty, so seems like we can remove it.

On the other hand, checking if its empty first would shortcut the tests that get performed inside of IsValidNamespace, so it might be a micro-optimization. I suppose would could achieve that same micro-optimization by starting off IsValidNamespace by checking if the string is empty.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

content.raw:
I think I've found the cause of the Windows issues, and it's just Microsoft documentation being confusing.

I changed the way we use the function `CreateProcess` to try to follow Microsoft's recommended use, but it turns out I didn't change it enough. I think we need to take the application name out of the arg list that gets passed to the function's second argument. I'm running a test with that change right now, and I'll push the fix if it works.

After looking at the Homebrew failures more carefully, I believe those are just race conditions. I'll stretch out the time limits for those tests to help them pass.
content.html:
I think I've found the cause of the Windows issues, and it's just Microsoft documentation being confusing.

I changed the way we use the function CreateProcess to try to follow Microsoft's recommended use, but it turns out I didn't change it enough. I think we need to take the application name out of the arg list that gets passed to the function's second argument. I'm running a test with that change right now, and I'll push the fix if it works.

After looking at the Homebrew failures more carefully, I believe those are just race conditions. I'll stretch out the time limits for those tests to help them pass.

content.raw:
I've confirmed that these failures are recreated on my Windows virtual machine. When I tested the `default` branch instead, only one failure occurred, but that may have been a race condition on a flaky test, as opposed to a logic error.

I've begun investigating the cause. I'll post an update as soon as I've found something.
content.html:
I've confirmed that these failures are recreated on my Windows virtual machine. When I tested the default branch instead, only one failure occurred, but that may have been a race condition on a flaky test, as opposed to a logic error.

I've begun investigating the cause. I'll post an update as soon as I've found something.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

content.raw:
I'm noticing that the tests on Windows and Homebrew have some very surprising logic failures.

If they were performance/timing failures, I wouldn't have been surprised, but things like `counter` being wrong would normally indicate logical failures. It's especially strange because these failures seem to be inconsistent between the two, and Xenial has no failures at all.

I'm going to run tests on my Windows virtual machine before reapproving this PR.
content.html:
I'm noticing that the tests on Windows and Homebrew have some very surprising logic failures.

If they were performance/timing failures, I wouldn't have been surprised, but things like counter being wrong would normally indicate logical failures. It's especially strange because these failures seem to be inconsistent between the two, and Xenial has no failures at all.

I'm going to run tests on my Windows virtual machine before reapproving this PR.

content.raw: Note for reviewers: This is the recommended way of using `CreateProcess` according to Microsoft documentation. Apparently this guards against misbehavior that can be caused by spaces in file names.
content.html: Note for reviewers: This is the recommended way of using CreateProcess according to Microsoft documentation. Apparently this guards against misbehavior that can be caused by spaces in file names.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

content.raw: Another note for reviewers: This value (and the value on line 265) needed to be made public and static so that users (in this case, the logging framework, which is essentially a user of `ign-transport`) can easily perform discovery on message and service advertisements.
content.html: Another note for reviewers: This value (and the value on line 265) needed to be made public and static so that users (in this case, the logging framework, which is essentially a user of ign-transport) can easily perform discovery on message and service advertisements.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport

content.raw:
For other reviewers, I'd like to point out that these functions were removed because they did not have definitions (i.e. if someone tried to call these functions, they would get a linker error).

Rather than giving definitions to these functions, I think it's sufficient to allow users to access this information through a const-qualified `Options()` function, so we've removed the declarations altogether and made `Options()` a public const function.
content.html:
For other reviewers, I'd like to point out that these functions were removed because they did not have definitions (i.e. if someone tried to call these functions, they would get a linker error).

Rather than giving definitions to these functions, I think it's sufficient to allow users to access this information through a const-qualified Options() function, so we've removed the declarations altogether and made Options() a public const function.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 1: Misc changes to ignition transport
